comments.commentBody:
Of the many methods and tactics to impede North Korea's ballistic missile and miniaturized thermonuclear warhead programs mentioned in this article, perhaps the most obvious, most rational, potentially the most rewarding and productive, and surely the least dangerous course of action has strangely gone unmentioned: diplomacy, as in (for example) formal peace talks to (finally) put an end to the stalemate on the Korean peninsula. The surest way to reduce or eliminate the threat of a North Korean nuclear strike on the US is to deprive the North of a reason to strike.

Likewise absent in this article is the extraordinarily complex historical background to the present situation, that is to say, context. The problem on the peninsula goes back at least to the 1910 Japanese occupation. No solution will avail without solving the larger longstanding issues that were placed on hold in 1953.

Given the enormous risks of continuing down the present path of accelerating confrontation and exceptionally dangerous sabotage and subversion, wouldn't it be wise to talk?
Yeah, yeah, we'll get to the diplomacy thing right after we cut the state department by 1/3.

I agree - but this guy in the North is crazy..  China is their only "friend".  Yet China's President has never met with him.   That is telling.  The guy just assassinated his own brother - who was being protected by China.  I fear no diplomacy works with a mad man like that.
Yes.....quiet diplomacy was President Obama's greatest legacy to this country.....

Acton: “the tweet could come to be seen as a ‘red line’ and hence set up a potential test of his credibility.”

As a starting point, let's acknowledge that Trump has no credibility, the result of his well-known and well-documented lies. Nothing he says should be believed, especially his tweets.

However he once said that he likes to be unpredictable, and that is certainly what he has become. He has Washington, America, and the world guessing about what he will say next, how serious it will be, and above all, what he will actually do.

But he is as incompetent about governing as he is inclined to lie. Contempt for facts and incompetence is a frighteningly dangerous combination for a commander in chief facing a profound military challenge like the one in this report. Not predicting it, but be aware: Trump could very well ignite a war in Asia, with obviously disastrous consequences.

"I inherited a mess". Oh my I had a good laugh over that one!

Of course you did, the world is a messy place. The dynamics of which change constantly, a multitude of moving parts and the U.S. at the center of it all.

But what I initially laughed over was the contrast of the scene when his predecessor came into office and when he arrived. Night and day difference. Obama handed over a pretty smooth sailing ship compared to the stormy waters W have him.

Growing up Jewish in the 50's , in my house you just didn't mention the word Jesus , although my mother would remind me from time to time that "Jesus was Jewish you know ".

I never understood the full meaning of that until I saw a biography on the history channel about Jesus Christ where I really learned about this religious compassionate Jew named Jesus who stayed away from home worrying his mother , as he spent hours teaching the Talmud to his Jewish community when the Romans had fobidden it .

This Jewish scholar was an activist among his poor Jewish people who bravely fought when their land was taken away from them after Romans added such high taxes to the point that the amount of taxes was more than their income. The only way to pay off their taxes was to sell their land.

Ever since I saw that documentary , I have felt even prouder to be Jewish and proud of this great Jew named Jesus who fought the establishment, helped the poor, and worked to spread good will throughout the corrupt world he was living in. He was a hero.

Whether or not I believe that Jesus was the son of God is irrelevant . He did exist, he was a Jew , he was a good Jew and isn't that all we need for us to come together as Jews and Christians and say that are we are all on the same page with this ?

I love Pope Francis . He is a true leader who has the courage to be fearless from the binds of politics.

Now , get Ryan back to Catechism .
...and put women in positions of authority in the church. Now you're talking!

A decade ago, I went to Paris with my uncle and aunt and we were staying in the 16th Arrondissement.

On our way to the Metro my uncle told me to give 15 euros to the homeless guy over there...I gave him a "fuggedaboutit" look. I was quickly admonished and reminded that his father, my grandfather, always reminded us that: 1] don't be selfish, 2] remember that the "bum" could be Jesus testing us to make certain we are following his words in Matthew 19 “If you would be perfect, go and sell what you have, and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. And come, follow Me.” and 3] always remember the golden rule.

It was the reawakening after so many years...of lessons learned as a child and that EVERYONE on this planet should be treated with dignity and respect.
Compassion, yes, but care NOT cash!

Many Americans no doubt share the mindset of one reader as reflected in his rhetorical question: "How can we be so incredibly stupid to allow this regime to become such a threat to its neighbors and the world." Implicit in this question is the belief that it is America's right, if not duty, to act unilaterally to prevent other nations to become threats to their neighbors and the world.

I for one am very uncomfortable with such a belief and those who hold it, especially if they are in the White House. For if anything our post WWII experience taught us, it is unilateral interventionism is to be avoided whenever possible, unless of course a real and immediate danger to our defense is threatened.

I daresay America is disliked (hated even) and distrusted in most of the world despite what our politicians tell us to the contrary. Some of this animus is envy driven, but most is surely due to the perception that we use our tremendous power and wealth to bully and exploit other nations. Whenever we have acted militarily or covertly on a unilateral or phony multilateral basis, this perception is magnified in the eyes of other nations.

Any action against N. Korea should be undertaken through the UN. If that is not possible, then with Japan and S. Korea and other neighbors more threatened by N. Korea than the U.S. is. If those neighbors don't feel threatened enough to genuinely join us in taking military action against N. Korea, we would be fools again to do so unilaterally.
"I daresay America is disliked (hated even) and distrusted in most of the world...?"....... And even half the people who live here!

First, no nation has been as powerful and wealth as the USA. Second, our magnanimousness is not equivalent to what other, less powerful and less wealthy offer poor nations in terms of foreign aid relative to GNP. Third, our altruism is about to take a major hit under Trump's proposed cutbacks in foreign aid. And last, but not least, the magnanimousness we have exhibited in the Islamic world is in direct proportion to the suffering, destruction and instability unleashed by our "War on Terror" there. Whether we will fix what we broke, let alone what was broken before we invaded, bombed and occupied, is highly doubtful.

You are largely correct. But the feebleness of the UN is precisely what we, the USSR and other wannabe major powers like Britain and France wanted when the UN Charter was negotiated and approved. However, the idea of a genuinely empowered international system of laws and entities of governance are, IMHO, the only means by which humanity can be saved from itself will be by the elimination or mitigation of the major causes of war and other significant human conflict, poverty, starvation, degradation and pollution of the environment and earth's ecosystems, and depletion of the remaining natural resources.

As history teaches (to those who listen and read anyway), those causes are nationalism, religion, unrestrained greed, and deprivation of basic human freedoms. I'm convinced the only way this can be accomplished is through a truly united nations organization with its own army, navy and air force, with the elimination of all national borders and sovereignty, and with the adoption of an international constitution similar to the USA's that guarantees individual freedoms, provides for the rule of law, and protects ethnic, property, religious and cultural rights of all. Until Trump I would have said the world should be governed democratically, but I'm no longer confident that voters anywhere can be trusted. Perhaps if safeguards not in the US Constitution are adopted, such demagogues can never be elected. But of course the US will never give up its sovereignty--voluntarily.
Mine too! I like to get Poped up...makes me feel more human, and a little braver as well.

My guess is that this information was purposefully leaked to the press by intelligence and defense agencies as a desperate measure to get the attention of the White House.  As we know, the administration has been generally ignoring/declining intelligence briefings, and has rendered the diplomatic arm of our government (State Dept) impotent.

And when has the Catholic Church EVER given out bad advice?  Thank you Francis for this brilliant dictum.  Happy that in contributing to alcoholism and drug addiction, I will appear to be non-judgemental.  At last an opportunity to feel good about myself.

Then God will judge them.  I think the idea that Francis is making is that the gift or lack of gift relects on your warmth and compassion.  Jesus said that when you see hunger and you so not feed them then you did not feed me.  He did not say unless they might go get a fix.  You are looking for ways to salve your guilt of not giving to the poor.  Even giving to the charities connected with churches does not fufill the command that Jesus made when he said if you do not care for the poor then you will not make heaven.

Giving something for short term happiness to someone who sees little of it seems gracious and caring; better than your all-knowing, hubris inspired and I-know-better-than-you technique. Please tell us how this has managed to help eradicate homelessness?

My mom, a coffee shop waitress for 60 years, ALWAYS gave.  Then she would turn to me and say, "I always say little girl, there but for the grace of God.  There but for the grace of God."  Compassion and humility.  She would have loved this Pope.
Cheeseheads indeed. I won't be buying Wisconsin Cheese anymore. Let us know how that works out for your state's power. You're just a trouble maker, just like the punk Trump.

'Healthcare is complicated". Single payer would make it much less complicated. That has to be done by a federal government.

The environment is complicated too. The pesticides and fertilizers used by Pennsylvania wash down rivers and streams to pollute the Chesapeake Bay.

States can and do effect each other. This is why we are the United Staes of America.

Fine, return it all to the states.  Cool.  Remember to return the taxes too.  The red states will utterly collapse and anyone who is able will flee to the blue states where the actual revenue is generated.  Scott Walker's Wisconsin will become a wasteland.  What a plan.

Agreed. Totally.
In my (long-ish) life time there's been almost no real progress, in terms of legislation, in our Nation simply because these rural/suburban Republicans are like a millstone around our necks. The last truly effective legislative move was the Clean Air Act. Or maybe Title IX.
It's time to break that chain, move on. This would be a very good start.

1) So his advice, as an elected official, is for elected politicians to ignore their constituents?
2) He makes it sound as if the economic recovery, experienced by the entire country, was his doing! Ha!
3) There is absolutely no evidence to suggest that if taxes come from the state they will fund effective programs, but if they're collected by the federal government and then returned to the states (as much of federal funding is), they will fund ineffective programs.

If there should be "more power to the states" then let California and other states that desire to do so regulate their own air quality standards, fuel emission standards, CO2 and methane emissions, and clean energy standards.  It is they height of hypocrisy to assert "states' rights" and then try to gut them!  We in California have no desire to live life in ignorance of the actual facts.  And we certainly have no desire to breathe Delhi- or Beijing-quality air.  If "Middle America" desires to become further economically uncompetitive so be it.  We in California have a strong desire to advance humanity, "Middle America" be damned.

You can't really expect hacks like Walker to pay attention to evidence or data. As far as he is concerned, Wisconsin is doing well because it's following republican political positions; little matter Wisconsin is not doing as well as a neighboring state doing things differently.

What's clear is that when fully and strictly implemented, republican tax-cutting policies result in deterioration of essential services. Just look at Kansas.

Walker is once again using alternative facts.  Lowers job growth in the 10 Midwest states.  Road construction non existent.  Education funding down.  I ask so called trickle down purists if tax cuts are a panacea, would no taxes be better?

A lot of gov't laws are written to address abuses in the business community.  Is the business community local?  Is it even national?  It's global.  Missouri can have environmental laws less restrictive than Ohio: all that tells XYZ corporation, operating in Ohio, is where to dump its toxic pollutants.  Should people live their healthy younger lives in Wisconsin, then retire to Arizona to take health benefits from a state they didn't pay into when they were healthy?  We already have a problem in this country with wealthy people parking their money offshore.  Shall we make it easier for them to park their money out of state?  Apparently so.  It's every man for himself in these Republican 'United' States.

Republicans already passed judgment on Governor Scott Walker, determining the he is not ready for prime time. Democrats would characterize his ability and ideas in even harsher terms.

Putting aside, however, Governor Walker’s shortcomings, the fact is that he brings nothing new to the table.

Beyond an anti-union rant and dredging up old, discredited myths of lazy (read: black) welfare queens, Governor Walker has nothing to say.

Whenever the discussion turns to reality-based specifics, Republican politicians literally run.

They are comfortable only when trotting out slogans, and they dismiss any true populist concern for American citizens who are trying to protect themselves and their families from a broken system.

There is no better example of duty-shirking Republicans than their dishonest handling of the Affordable Care Act. Better to let low-income working people die in the streets from illnesses which are easily cured or managed for people of means.

If that spectacle is too much even for Republicans to stomach, then force the poor or near-poor to receive medical care only in the most expensive venues – the nation’s Emergency Rooms. More affluent Americans – and that includes most of us – will pay the unnecessary upcharge in the form of high hospital bills across the board. At least Republicans will not be caught showing any mercy.

The dirty secret is that Obamacare has been working, and Republicans don’t have a clue of what to do other than to gut it.

When I read a conservative discuss a topic with the lead; "Our founding fathers..." I immediately begin to laugh. Our 'founding fathers' lived in an entirely different time. Our founding fathers, if transported to 2017 would see how different the world is and would themselves debate again, 'states rights' in the reality of today's world. If Gov. Walker were to really implement states rights in the area of healthcare coverage, the results would be disastrous for states who do not value healthcare for its citizens.Every American should have access to healthcare for one simple reason. The role of government is to protect its citizens, every citizen equally. States rights advocates are working to establish a system of governance with built-in unequal treatment of our citizens healthcare access.
